body_html:
Please do try to fill in all the information asked for the in issue template (https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/new), without that it is somewhat hard to help.

In this particular case, what platform are you running on?
Seems like you have a very old version of glibc (2.2.5 is from 2002 I believe - as per https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/Glibc%20Timeline)

If that is the case, and you're unable to use a more modern version of glibc, then you could try compiling from source - though I'm not sure that it will work.

To build from sources see https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/java#building-from-source

And once you have the native libraries (libtensorflow_framework.so and libtensorflow_jni.so) built, you could simply copy them to a directory an include that directory in the java.library.path property provided to the JVM.

Hope that helps.

body:
Please do try to fill in all the information asked for the in issue template (https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/new), without that it is somewhat hard to help.

In this particular case, what platform are you running on?  
Seems like you have a very old version of glibc (2.2.5 is from 2002 I believe - as per https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/Glibc%20Timeline)

If that is the case, and you're unable to use a more modern version of glibc, then you could try compiling from source - though I'm not sure that it will work.

To build from sources see https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/java#building-from-source 

And once you have the native libraries (`libtensorflow_framework.so` and `libtensorflow_jni.so`) built, you could simply copy them to a directory an include that directory in the `java.library.path` property provided to the JVM.

Hope that helps.
